title: Semi-serif
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Terminology](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Terminology) : Semi-serif**

A post-modernist category of typeface that mixes elements of both the [serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/wiki/serif) and [sans serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/wiki/sans%20serif) forms.

**Discussion:**  
 [Other sans-serif/serif hybrids besides Dead History?](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/node/13079)  
 [The Best Term for a Typeface That Combines Elements of Both Serif and Sans Serif?](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020161359/http:/typophile.com/node/29946)

\<--! Note: I'm not sure this is the right term, as there are straight text fonts with "Semiserif" in the name. "Hybrid" something or "Mashup" might be a more appropriate wiki page for this type of font. - S. Coles

Note: Stephen, i'm not sure how the term "semi-serif" is used in reference to these other types of fonts. Can you point me toward some samples, so that I can expand this article to include both usages? --\>
author: paul d hunt
